docs.lead_paragraph: Simple white crosses and pinwheels spinning quietly in the breeze mark the graves of 38 abandoned babies buried in a cemetery here. Anonymous in death, the babies were given names and proper funerals by a stranger. The efforts of that stranger, Debi Faris, a mother of three from Yucaipa, 80 miles east of Los Angeles, began more than three years ago when she heard the story of an infant found dead in a duffel bag along a road in Los Angeles and wanted to give the baby a proper burial. After making certain Ms. Faris had no connection to the case, the county coroner gave permission, then asked if she would take two others, who would otherwise be cremated, put in a cardboard box and given a number.

headline.main: Deaths of Unwanted Babies Prompt Calls to Ease Laws

docs.abstract: Lawmakers and prosecutors nationwide weigh changes in laws to reduce or eliminate number of abandoned infants found dead each year; changes would allow parents to avoid prosecution for child abandonment if they leave babies in safe place; campaign by Calimesa, Calif, resident Debi Faris, who is pushing for state legislation to offer legal protections to parents who abandon children in safe places, discussed; she has started Garden of Angels, small burial area in cemetery near San Bernardino; bought 42 graves for abandoned children with $27,000 in personal funds; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Simple white crosses and pinwheels spinning quietly in the breeze mark the graves of 38 abandoned babies buried in a cemetery here. Anonymous in death, the babies were given names and proper funerals by a stranger.    The efforts of that stranger,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sandra Schmirler, the star of the first women's curling team to win an Olympic gold medal and one of Canada's most popular athletes, died Thursday in Regina, Saskatchewan. She was 36. She died of cancer, the Canadian Curling Association said.

headline.main: Sandra Schmirler, 36, Dies; Olympic Curling Champion

docs.abstract: Sandra Schmirler, star of 1998 Canadian curling team that won gold medal at 1998 Winter Olympics, dies at age 36; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Sandra Schmirler, the star of the first women's curling team to win an Olympic gold medal and one of Canada's most popular athletes, died Thursday in Regina, Saskatchewan. She was 36.    She died of cancer, the Canadian Curling Association said.

docs.lead_paragraph: A brief report in Science Times on Tuesday about a comparison of teenage pregnancy rates around the world misspelled the name of the president of the Alan Guttmacher Institute, which produced the study. She is Sara Seims, not Reims.
docs.abstract: Correction of Feb 29 report comparing teenage pregnancy rates around the world, regarding name of president of Alan Guttmacher Institute, Sara Seims
docs.snippet: A brief report in Science Times on Tuesday about a comparison of teenage pregnancy rates around the world misspelled the name of the president of the Alan Guttmacher Institute, which produced the study. She is Sara Seims, not Reims.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A Feb. 25 letter writer asserts: ''Women need abortion options for physical, emotional and financial reasons. Abortion empowers women by providing an alternative to an unwanted pregnancy.'' Although an abortion-rights supporter, I find this reasoning appalling. By this logic, a woman should have the right to terminate the life of her month-old baby if doing so would improve her emotional or financial well-being, or ''empower'' her by providing an alternative to unwanted motherhood.
docs.abstract: Dan Kahn letter scores reasoning in Feb 25 letter arguing that 'women need abortion options for physical, emotional and financial reasons'
